trans-unit.source: Scheduling a runbook in Azure Automation
trans-unit.target: Scheduling a runbook in Azure Automation

trans-unit.source: Describes how to create a schedule in Azure Automation so that you can automatically start a runbook at a particular time or on a recurring schedule.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to create a schedule in Azure Automation so that you can automatically start a runbook at a particular time or on a recurring schedule.

trans-unit.source: Scheduling a runbook in Azure Automation
trans-unit.target: Scheduling a runbook in Azure Automation

trans-unit.source: To schedule a runbook in Azure Automation to start at a specified time, you link it to one or more schedules.
trans-unit.target: To schedule a runbook in Azure Automation to start at a specified time, you link it to one or more schedules.

trans-unit.source: A schedule can be configured to either run one time or recurring every specified number of hours or days.
trans-unit.target: A schedule can be configured to either run one time or recurring every specified number of hours or days.

trans-unit.source: A runbook can be linked to multiple schedules, and a schedule can have multiple runbooks linked to it.
trans-unit.target: A runbook can be linked to multiple schedules, and a schedule can have multiple runbooks linked to it.

trans-unit.source: Creating a schedule
trans-unit.target: Creating a schedule

trans-unit.source: You can either create a new schedule with the Azure Management Portal or with Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: You can either create a new schedule with the Azure Management Portal or with Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: You also have the option of creating a new schedule when you link a runbook to a schedule using the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: You also have the option of creating a new schedule when you link a runbook to a schedule using the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: To create a new schedule with the Azure Management Portal
trans-unit.target: To create a new schedule with the Azure Management Portal

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, select Automation and then then click the name of an automation account.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, select Automation and then then click the name of an automation account.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Assets** tab.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Assets** tab.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the window, click **Add Setting**.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the window, click **Add Setting**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Add Schedule**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Add Schedule**.

trans-unit.source: Type a **Name** and optionally a **Description** for the new schedule.
trans-unit.target: Type a **Name** and optionally a **Description** for the new schedule.

trans-unit.source: Select whether the schedule will run **One Time**, **Hourly**, or **Daily**.
trans-unit.target: Select whether the schedule will run **One Time**, **Hourly**, or **Daily**.

trans-unit.source: Specify a **Start Time** and other options depending on the type of schedule that you selected.
trans-unit.target: Specify a **Start Time** and other options depending on the type of schedule that you selected.

trans-unit.source: To create a new schedule with Windows PowerShell
trans-unit.target: To create a new schedule with Windows PowerShell

trans-unit.source: You can use the [New-AzureAutomationSchedule](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn690271.aspx) cmdlet to create a new schedule in Azure Automation.
trans-unit.target: You can use the [New-AzureAutomationSchedule](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn690271.aspx) cmdlet to create a new schedule in Azure Automation.

trans-unit.source: You must specify the start time for the schedule and whether it should run one time, hourly, or daily.
trans-unit.target: You must specify the start time for the schedule and whether it should run one time, hourly, or daily.

trans-unit.source: The following sample commands show how to create a new schedule that runs each day at 3:30 PM starting on January 20, 2015.
trans-unit.target: The following sample commands show how to create a new schedule that runs each day at 3:30 PM starting on January 20, 2015.

trans-unit.source: Linking a schedule to a runbook
trans-unit.target: Linking a schedule to a runbook

trans-unit.source: A runbook can be linked to multiple schedules, and a schedule can have multiple runbooks linked to it.
trans-unit.target: A runbook can be linked to multiple schedules, and a schedule can have multiple runbooks linked to it.

trans-unit.source: If a runbook has parameters, then you can provide values for them.
trans-unit.target: If a runbook has parameters, then you can provide values for them.

trans-unit.source: You must provide values for any mandatory parameters and may provide values for any optional parameters.
trans-unit.target: You must provide values for any mandatory parameters and may provide values for any optional parameters.

trans-unit.source: These values will be used each time the runbook is started by this schedule.
trans-unit.target: These values will be used each time the runbook is started by this schedule.

trans-unit.source: You can attach the same runbook to another schedule and specify different parameter values.
trans-unit.target: You can attach the same runbook to another schedule and specify different parameter values.

trans-unit.source: To link a schedule to a runbook with the Azure Management Portal
trans-unit.target: To link a schedule to a runbook with the Azure Management Portal

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, select **Automation** and then then click the name of an automation account.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, select **Automation** and then then click the name of an automation account.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Runbooks** tab.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Runbooks** tab.

trans-unit.source: Click on the name of the runbook to schedule.
trans-unit.target: Click on the name of the runbook to schedule.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Schedule** tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Schedule** tab.

trans-unit.source: If the runbook is not currently linked to a schedule, then you will be given the option to **Link to a New Schedule** or **Link to an Existing Schedule**.
trans-unit.target: If the runbook is not currently linked to a schedule, then you will be given the option to **Link to a New Schedule** or **Link to an Existing Schedule**.

trans-unit.source: If the runbook is currently linked to a schedule, click **Link** at the bottom of the window to access these options.
trans-unit.target: If the runbook is currently linked to a schedule, click **Link** at the bottom of the window to access these options.

trans-unit.source: If the runbook has parameters, you will be prompted for their values.
trans-unit.target: If the runbook has parameters, you will be prompted for their values.

trans-unit.source: To link a schedule to a runbook with Windows PowerShell
trans-unit.target: To link a schedule to a runbook with Windows PowerShell

trans-unit.source: You can use the [Register-AzureAutomationScheduledRunbook](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn690265.aspx) to link a schedule to a runbook.
trans-unit.target: You can use the [Register-AzureAutomationScheduledRunbook](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn690265.aspx) to link a schedule to a runbook.

trans-unit.source: You can specify values for the runbook’s parameters with the Parameters parameter.
trans-unit.target: You can specify values for the runbook’s parameters with the Parameters parameter.

trans-unit.source: See [Starting a Runbook in Azure Automation](automation-starting-a-runbook.md) for more information on specifying parameter values.
trans-unit.target: See [Starting a Runbook in Azure Automation](automation-starting-a-runbook.md) for more information on specifying parameter values.

trans-unit.source: The following sample commands show how to link a schedule to a runbook with parameters.
trans-unit.target: The following sample commands show how to link a schedule to a runbook with parameters.

trans-unit.source: Disabling a schedule
trans-unit.target: Disabling a schedule

trans-unit.source: When you disable a schedule, any runbooks linked to it will no longer run on that schedule.
trans-unit.target: When you disable a schedule, any runbooks linked to it will no longer run on that schedule.

trans-unit.source: You can manually disable a schedule or set an expiration time for Hourly and Daily schedules when you create them.
trans-unit.target: You can manually disable a schedule or set an expiration time for Hourly and Daily schedules when you create them.

trans-unit.source: When the expiration time is reached, the schedule will be disabled.
trans-unit.target: When the expiration time is reached, the schedule will be disabled.

trans-unit.source: To disable a schedule with the Azure Management Portal
trans-unit.target: To disable a schedule with the Azure Management Portal

trans-unit.source: You can disable a schedule in the Azure Management Portal from the Schedule Details page for the schedule.
trans-unit.target: You can disable a schedule in the Azure Management Portal from the Schedule Details page for the schedule.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, select Automation and then then click the name of an automation account.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, select Automation and then then click the name of an automation account.

trans-unit.source: Select the Assets tab.
trans-unit.target: Select the Assets tab.

trans-unit.source: Click the name of a schedule to open its detail page.
trans-unit.target: Click the name of a schedule to open its detail page.

trans-unit.source: Change **Enabled** to **No**.
trans-unit.target: Change **Enabled** to **No**.

trans-unit.source: To disable a schedule with Windows PowerShell
trans-unit.target: To disable a schedule with Windows PowerShell

trans-unit.source: You can use the [Set-AzureAutomationSchedule](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn690270.aspx) cmdlet to change the properties of an existing schedule.
trans-unit.target: You can use the [Set-AzureAutomationSchedule](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn690270.aspx) cmdlet to change the properties of an existing schedule.

trans-unit.source: To disable the schedule, specify **false** for the **IsEnabled** parameter.
trans-unit.target: To disable the schedule, specify **false** for the **IsEnabled** parameter.

trans-unit.source: The following sample commands show how to disable a schedule.
trans-unit.target: The following sample commands show how to disable a schedule.
